Award.AbstractNarration: This award is made as part of the FY 2015 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Daniel Lacker is "Large deviations and concentration inequalities for mean field games." The host institution for the fellowship is Brown University, and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Kavita Raman.

Performance_Institution.Name: Brown University, Division of Applied Mathematics

POR.DRECONTENT:
Mean field theory was originally developed to study particle systems (gases, fluids, etc.) but has since emerged as a widespread mathematical foundation for studying a broader class of systems. The key insight of this approach is that the infinite-population "mean field limit" of a finite-population model often effectively approximates macroscopic and statistical features of the system as well as the behavior of a typical or average particle. Applications of traditional mean field theory in the social sciences are plentiful, but a major weakness is their inability to model individuals as decision-makers. 
 
Mean field game (MFG) theory tackles this shortcoming by incorporating individual choice. In traditional mean field models individuals follow prescribed laws of motion, while MFG models they are free to optimize in face of some given incentive structures. Imagine, for example, a driver choosing a route to minimize travel time, a manufacturer choosing how much to produce, or an investor maximizing returns. MFG theory again facilitates succinct descriptions of the behavior of a typical individual as well as the distribution of states across the population and over time (e.g., the distribution of traffic in a network, or the income distribution in an economy). Whereas competitive (Nash) equilibria of large competitive systems are usually difficult to analyze, MFG theory provides more tractable infinite-population limits that retain important statistical features of finite systems.
 
This NSF proposal led to significant advances in our understanding of the precise nature in which the "mean field limit" approximates the original finite-population model. Previous research showed that the finite models are close to the mean field (infinite-population) models given a sufficiently large population size. The main outcome of the research supported by this NSF award is a method for quantifying this approximation. For the first time, we can calculate in these models the precise effects of population size. This comes mainly in the form of so-called large deviation principles, which describe how rare deviations from the mean field limit can occur in large but finite populations. A particularly important application is in the modeling of systemic risk (e.g., in inter-bank lending networks), wherein a large-scale default or failure of many components of a system is precisely the kind of rare event captured by large deviations theory. The research supported by this award made additional breakthroughs in the form of non-asymptotic concentration estimates, fluctuation theorems, limit theorems for cooperative (as opposed to competitive) systems, and applications of MFG theory to models of optimal investment and network traffic routing.
 
With the support of this award, the PI presented the research in several workshops and conferences, including the SIAM Conference on Financial Mathematics and Engineering (2016) and the 8th Western Conference in Mathematical Finance (2017). In addition, the PI participated in Brown University's Math CoOp, a fairly new but growing program in which participants prepare and deliver presentations at local grade school programs, exposing students to exciting ideas and applications of mathematics.
